title: Economic Growth and Economic Performance Over The Long Run: Frontier Research in Economic and Social History
abstractText:
Recently, there has been an increased interest in economic history amongst academics, policy makers and the media, stimulated not least by the current financial crisis and "great recession", leading many to turn to the history of the Great Depression to provide some answers as to why this has happened and which policies can alleviate the situation. 

Economists have increasingly started to look at issues of growth, financial crises and globalisation using a long time series of data. Economic history is also very useful as a testing ground for current policy debates concerning the effects of immigration, technological change and government intervention in the economy.  In a series of conferences, we will invite presenters to explore and discuss these types of issues. 

The first conference will relate particularly to financial crises in history, the second to labor markets and immigration in historical perspective and the final conference will explore gender issues.
